demonstrated that the diffusive regime is a finite-size ef- fect, whereby anomalous behavior is recovered for :formula: large enough [37, 38] (see also the discussion based on mode- coupling arguments in Ref. [39]).
In this Letter we present a general explanation of the counter-intuitive normal transport, by tracing it back to the vicinity to an integrable limit. In this context, the kinetics is dominated by quasi-particles (those associated to the integrals of motion of the integrable regime, e.g., solitons) over a broad range of scales. In fact, this range extends beyond the very large quasi-particle mean free path, where a purely ballistic behavior is expected. More specifically, we proceed by first devising a finite-size scal- ing approach and then validating the theoretical argu- ments with the numerical analysis of a few test models.
Let the parameter :formula: denote the distance from the in- tegrable limit :formula: corresponding to the perfectly in- tegrable regime). Building upon the intuition contained in Ref. [40], we propose that for small &, the heat flux :formula: can be written as the sum of two terms,

For equal masses :formula: both models are com- pletely integrable: in the HPG, the constants of motion are the initial velocities, while in the Toda model the conserved actions are given functions of positions and momenta [49, 50]. Both models can be seen as gases of quasi-particles: velocitons for HPG [51] and solitons for Toda [47]. Transport is ballistic: :formula: is proportional to :formula: and the energy-current correlation function does not decay to zero at large times [52, 53]. Note that, accord- ing to the classification of Ref. [54], the two models are noninteracting and interacting, respectively.
Here below, we consider two different ways of break- ing integrability (i.e. to induce interactions among the quasi-particles): (i) different masses, such as a diatomic arrangement whereby :formula: :formula: :formula: for odd (even) n [44-46]; (ii) a con- servative noise through random collisions exchanging the momenta of neighboring particles at a given rate :formula: [35] (see also a related model in Ref. [55]). In the former (latter) case :formula: plays the role of the above mentioned closeness parameter &. In either case, only three con- servation laws survive, momentum, energy and stretch, yielding anomalous transport and dynamical scaling [56]. For large enough ô-values, there is overwhelming evidence that both the diatomic HPG and Toda [45] belong to the KPZ universality class. For the randomly perturbed Toda evidence of a diverging conductivity is solid, yield- ing :formula: for a large collision rate :formula: [35].

For the HPG we employ the thermal-wall method as detailed, e.g., in Ref. [36].
In Fig. 1(a) we plot the rescaled thermal conductivity :formula: of the diatomic HPG, referred to the effective length :formula: [57] (the various curves correspond to different :formula: values - :formula: decreases from top to bottom). There is clear evidence of a ballistic regime followed by a diffusive one, as accounted for by Eq. (3). For the smaller 0's, Fourier-like trasport persists up to the maximal available :formula: while a crossover to the anomalous regime is seen upon increasing :formula: (see the uppermost curve). proves remarkably accurate: see the solid upper curve in Fig. 2, to be compared with the circles, which represent the numerical HPG results.
As a second test, we consider the diatomic Toda model [36]. For large energy densities, most of its dynamical properties are basically equal to the HPG [58] and we thus expect again :formula: i.e. :formula: 2. At lower ener- gies, one should estimate the soliton scattering rates due to mass inhomogeneities; however there are no reason to expect a different scaling behavior. Indeed, the typi- cal thermalization time is of order :formula: in a wide energy range [59]. The conductivities taken from Ref. [36], are reported in Fig. 1(b) after a proper rescaling. The data collapse confirms the validity of our arguments.
Finally, we have considered the Toda model with con- servative noise. In this case, it is natural to argue that the mean free path scales as the inverse of the collision rate, :formula: This intuition is confirmed by the data reported in Fig. 1(c), where we observe the same scenario as for the previous models, after setting :formula: 1. For small :formula: :formula: converges again towards a function which asymptotically decays as :formula: However, the heuristic formula (4) is not comparably accurate: it is necessary to add a correction term to reproduce the observed data as shown in Fig. 2 (see triangles :formula: the corresponding solid curve).
So far we have tested the structure of the first ad- dendum in Eq. (2), by studying a regime where the second contribution is negligible. What about the sec- ond addendum? Once :formula: has been determined, one can proceed by estimating the anomalous component as :formula: The data in Fig. 3 indicates that :formula: exhibits the expected anomalous scaling already for system sizes where the direct estimates are strongly affected by the diffusive component. For the HPG the fitted slope, about -0.66, corresponds to :formula: in ex- cellent agreement with the KPZ prediction :formula: For Toda we obtain :formula: consistent with Ref. [35] and even closer to :formula: the value rigorously proven for harmonic models with momentum-conserving noise [40- 42]. We thus conclude that the measurements are in full agreement with the crossover scenario from diffusive to hydrodynamic behavior proposed above.
The same scenario is expected to emerge in the pres- ence of generic momentum-conserving perturbations of the Toda chain, such as a potential of the form :formula: In fact, in this case, it has been already noticed that the energy-flux correlation decays over a time scale inversely proportional to a power of :formula: [53]. A preliminary evidence of a diffusive regime for small :formula: was also given in Ref. [60].
More in general, we argue that the crossover from normal to anomalous regimes of the :formula: model [37, 38] is fully accounted for by the above described sce- nario. Indeed, the :formula: (at low enough energies) can be regarded as a perturbed Toda chain over very long time scales, on which the Toda actions are only weakly perturbed [61]. We surmise that other model potentials

What can we say about the simplest model of a perturbed harmonic chain? This textbook case de- serves a special consideration. Numerical analysis of the FPUT-3 model at very low energy, i.e. below the strong stochasticity threshold, does not reveal any sig- nature of an intermediate diffusive regime, but rather a direct crossover from ballistic to anomalous regimes [62]. More compelling evidence of the absence of a diffusive regime comes from the study of the harmonic chain with conservative noise [41] in the limit of vanishing noise, i.e. :formula: It has been found analytically [40] and confirmed numerically [63] that :formula: exhibits a singular depen- dence for :formula: (here :formula: in the form of a divergence of the coefficient :formula: in Eq. (5), :formula: which im- plies that :formula: prevails over :formula: across the entire range of system sizes.
Hence, the different behavior displayed by weakly per- turbed harmonic oscillators can be traced back to a diver- gence of the anomalous component, which is itself a con- sequence of the nonlinearity of the dynamical equations. While this counter-intuitive phenomenon requires further clarifications, it does not however jeopardize the general scaling theory developed in this Letter, which provides a convincing explanation of the seemingly normal diffusion observed in several models of nonlinear chains.

SL is grateful to S. Ruffo and the program Collaborazioni :formula: Eccellenza of SISSA, Trieste, Italy.

solitons) over a broad range of scales. In fact, this range
extends beyond the very large quasi-particle mean free
path, where a purely ballistic behavior is expected. More
specifically, we proceed by first devising a finite-size scal-
ing approach and then validating the theoretical argu-
ments with the numerical analysis of a few test models.

where :formula: and the primed variables denote the values after the collision. Simulations are very efficient since they only require keeping track of the collisions [46].

For equal masses :formula: both models are com- pletely integrable: in the HPG, the constants of motion are the initial velocities, while in the Toda model the conserved actions are given functions of positions and momenta [49, 50]. Both models can be seen as gases of quasi-particles: velocitons for HPG [51] and solitons for Toda [47]. Transport is ballistic: :formula: is proportional to :formula: and the energy-current correlation function does not decay to zero at large times [52, 53]. Note that, accord- ing to the classification of Ref. [54], the two models are noninteracting and interacting, respectively.

[55]). In the former (latter) case :formula: plays the role of the above mentioned closeness parameter &. In either case, only three con- servation laws survive, momentum, energy and stretch, yielding anomalous transport and dynamical scaling [56]. For large enough ô-values, there is overwhelming evidence that both the diatomic HPG and Toda [45] belong to the KPZ universality class. So far we have tested the structure of the first ad- dendum in Eq. (2), by studying a regime where the second contribution is negligible. What about the sec- ond addendum? Once :formula: has been determined, one can proceed by estimating the anomalous component as :formula: The data in Fig. 3 indicates that :formula: exhibits the expected anomalous scaling already for system sizes where the direct estimates are strongly affected by the diffusive component. [35] and even closer to :formula: the value rigorously proven for harmonic models with momentum-conserving noise [40- 42]. We thus conclude that the measurements are in full agreement with the crossover scenario from diffusive to hydrodynamic behavior proposed above.

The same scenario is expected to emerge in the pres- ence of generic momentum-conserving perturbations of the Toda chain, such as a potential of the form :formula: In fact, in this case, it has been already noticed that the energy-flux correlation decays over a time scale inversely proportional to a power of :formula: [53]. More in general, we argue that the crossover from normal to anomalous regimes of the :formula: model [37, 38] is fully accounted for by the above described sce- nario. Indeed, the :formula: (at low enough energies) can be regarded as a perturbed Toda chain over very long time scales, on which the Toda actions are only weakly perturbed [61]. What can we say about the simplest model of a perturbed harmonic chain? This textbook case de- serves a special consideration. Numerical analysis of the FPUT-3 model at very low energy, i.e. below the strong stochasticity threshold, does not reveal any sig- nature of an intermediate diffusive regime, but rather a direct crossover from ballistic to anomalous regimes [62]. More compelling evidence of the absence of a diffusive regime comes from the study of the harmonic chain with conservative noise [41] in the limit of vanishing noise, i.e. :formula: It has been found analytically [40] and confirmed numerically [63] that :formula: exhibits a singular depen- dence for :formula: (here :formula: in the form of a divergence of the coefficient :formula: in Eq. (5), :formula: which im- plies that :formula: prevails over :formula: across the entire range of system sizes.

Hence, the different behavior displayed by weakly per- turbed harmonic oscillators can be traced back to a diver- gence of the anomalous component, which is itself a con- sequence of the nonlinearity of the dynamical equations. While this counter-intuitive phenomenon requires further clarifications, it does not however jeopardize the general scaling theory developed in this Letter, which provides a convincing explanation of the seemingly normal diffusion observed in several models of nonlinear chains.
